title: Councils warn of drastic cuts after Tories slip out 'hugely disappointing' funding deal
text:
News Councils warn of drastic cuts after Tories slip out 'hugely disappointing' funding deal A Tory town hall chief warned leisure centres and libraries may be slashed after the late-night details were published online Share Theresa May has repeatedly dismissed calls for more direct funding to councils (Photo: Barcroft) Share Get politics   Could   
Cash-strapped town halls slammed the government tonight for failing to give them new money. 
The Tory head of the Local Government Association (LGA) warned leisure centres and libraries may be slashed if a £5.8bn gap is not plugged. 
Councils had pleaded for new funds to prop up their budgets as they face a £2.6bn black hole for social care alone by 2020. 
But the final local government finance settlement for 2017/18 - slipped online by Tory ministers at 8pm tonight - made no offer beyond what was already known, the Local Government Association (LGA) said. Read More How much will my council tax be in 2017? Our payments calculator as bills soar for social care 
The LGA branded it "hugely disappointing". 
Mirror research shows more than half of social care councils plan to hike council tax by 4.99% - the maximum allowed without a referendum. 
But LGA chairman Lord Porter warned this was not enough as it will be swallowed up by wage bills, and the benefits vary hugely across the country. 
He said potholes could be left unfilled and children’s centres, leisure centres and libraries slashed if an overall £5.8bn gap by 2020 is not closed. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
